abstract.text: An on-device index for your app’s searchable content.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A
object manages an on-device index for your app’s
searchable content. To make your app’s content searchable, package it in
one or more
objects and add them to the index. You can
create as many searchable indexes as you need to manage your content,
and you can apply different levels of encryption to protect the content in
each index. When you execute a query, Core Spotlight searches your app’s
indexes for the requested information and returns the results to your code.
If your app creates
objects, set the
property of those objects to
to ensure they appear in search results.
Put your content into a custom
that you create.
Custom indexes support batch operations and additional levels of data
protection. Place sensitive personal information in protected indexes
to encrypt that content, and prevent its disclosure without proper
authorization from the owner of the device. Although you can put content into
the default index, you can’t encrypt the content in that index or
perform batch operations to add content to it.
When adding large amounts of data to the index, consider adding it in
batches to minimize risk. Batch-based updates make it easier to handle
errors that might occur during the indexing process. For each batch,
you provide client-state information to identify the current batch. If
your app or extension crashes while a batch operation is in progress,
you can use that state information to determine where to start indexing again later.
Modify custom
objects only on one thread or task at a
time. It’s a programming error to access a custom index from multiple threads
simultaneously. When performing batch updates on an index, start each new
batch operation only after calling the
or
method of the previous batch operation.

abstract.text: Add search capabilities to your app, and index your content so
people can find it from Spotlight and Safari.
An on-device index for your app’s searchable content.
Begins a batch of updates to an index.
Returns the default on-device index.
Deletes all searchable items from the index.
Deletes specific app entities from the system’s index.
Deletes all app entities of the given type from the system indices.
Removes from the index all searchable items associated with the specified domain.
Removes from the index all items with the specified identifiers.
Ends a batch of index updates and stores the specified state information.
Ends a batch of index updates and stores the specified state information.
Fetches data from an external provider.
Fetches the app’s most recent client state information asynchronously.
Indexes the provided entities into the system.
The delegate object that can handle index-management tasks.
Adds or updates items in the index.
Returns an on-device index with the specified name.
Returns an on-device index with the specified name and data protection class.
Returns a Boolean value that indicates whether indexing is available
on the current device.
A protocol that defines methods a delegate object or app extension uses to handle communication from the on-device index.
The details of your app-specific content that someone might search
for on their devices.
Create a description for your app’s content and add it to a Spotlight
index to make it searchable.

doc://com.apple.corespotlight/documentat.title: Adding your app’s content to Spotlight indexes

abstract.text: A representation of the state of your app at a moment in time.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the activity should be added to the on-device index.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
